characters: THEN THERE ARE OTHER SOUNDS EMANATING FROM THE DANGLING
WE RACK FOCUS ACROSS THE STREET TO THE POLICE
BACK TO STU IN THE BOOTH
RACK FOCUS TO THE POLICE SNIPER
BEING WHEELED AWAY FROM THE EMPTY BOOTH
RACK FOCUS BACK TO PHONE BOOTH
AS SEEN THROUGH CROSS HAIRS OF TELESCOPIC SIGHT

dialogues.speaker: MULTIPLE STREET SCENES
dialogues.text: The sidewalks crowded as usual.  A sea of humanity.  Peop come and go -- always in a hurry.  Oblivious of one anoth A TRAFFIC JAM -- A STREET being torn up by construction workers; A SANITATION TRUCK loading up refuse; VENDORS PEDDLING nuts and salted pretzels; PANHANDLERS blocking a passerby.  Intimidating.  Demanding.  Almost mocking. We're surrounded by the teeming life of the city as we've come to expect it -- complete with a cacophony of sound. MULTIPLE CUTS -- Phone kiosks and phone booths on the Eas Side and West Side -- uptown and down. One frustrated caller has lost his money in the slot and takes it out on the equipment -- smashing the receiver violently against the coin box until the instrument splin into a dozen pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are 237,911 pay telephones in the five burroughs of the city of New York.  Many of them are still in working order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEW YORKERS on the phone in extreme close up.  We don't h the words.  Only the facial expressions inform us that th are human beings under tremendous pressure.  Life in the is wearing them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lips jabbering into receivers.  Cross-cut against one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite increased usage of cellular devices, an estimated four and a half million New Yorkers and two million visitors still utilize pay telephones on a regular basis.  At thirty-five cents a pop... for the first three minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CORNER IN MID-MANHATTAN
dialogues.text: There's a phone booth situated on the southeast side of t street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking at the telephone booth at the corner of 45th Street and 8th Avenue in the heart of the Manhattan theatrical district.  It has been scheduled to be removed and replaced by a kiosk.  It's one of the few remaining phone booths left in the city. CAMERA MOVES IN on the irate caller in the booth -- a ver well-dressed gray-haired lady -- totally conservative in appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into receiver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have lied to me for the last time, you lowlife prick bastard!  I don't ever want to hear the sound of your fucking voice again. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well fuck you, too! She slams down the receiver and exits.  The booth remains vacant for a brief interval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least three hundred calls daily originate from this booth.  The coins are collected twice a day.  This booth has been burglarized forty-one times in the last six months. Someone is approaching the booth, fishing in his pocket f coins.  This is STUART SHEPARD, snappily dressed, his hai styled and his nails manicured.  Here is a man who clearl takes excellent care of himself.  He sports a Donna Karen suit and silk Armani tie. He's about to step into the booth when he's accosted by a middle-aged man in a soiled apron who's run out of a near restaurant and has finally caught up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu, we got to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could accommodate you, Mario, but this is my busy time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you cross the street every time you go past the restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I stop in later for some lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no more drinks or free meals until the restaurant starts showing up in the columns like you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing my level best for you people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One lousy mention in the Post and you expect to eat for six months!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the food critic from the Village Voice all lined up to give you a review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you tell me last July.  And he never shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was allowing you time to expand the menu.  Wallpaper the bathrooms, for God sakes.  You get only one shot with these fucking critics and I don't want you to blow a rare opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the one blowing it.  How long you think you can fuck everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on right there.  I've got a very excellent reputation around this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come you take two nice suits of clothes from Harry and never get his daughter on David Letterman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I'm not an agent.  I'm a publicist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, you're nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Valerie's on the waiting list to audition.  Harry's got no complaints.  He just let me pick out this tie the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Harry's a damn fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mario, please let me make this up to you.  How about I arrange for the opening night party for this new off-Broadway show I'm handling  -- to be held at your place with local TV coverage on nine and eleven?  I mean I had it promised to another client -- who actually pays me money.  But it isn't firmed up yet.  And I could throw it your way.  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is involved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd toss in the buffet for say seventy or eighty.  The producers would supply their own vino, of course.  I'd deliver you a truckload of celebrities.  And if they like the food, they'll all come back, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What celebrities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Liza Minelli?  An Oscar winner.  Or Douglas Fairbanks, Jr.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him last night going into the Four Seasons.  I'll bring you over a whole VIP list when we come by for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come everybody wants to eat but nobody wants to pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't think small like that.  Hey, you still feature musicians Fridays and Saturdays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least they work for their meals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Harry's daughter as an extra added attraction?  She'll belt out five or six showtunes -- two sets a night -- and it won't cost you a fucking nickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Star Showcase!  Let me handle setting that up.  And when she eventually goes on Letterman, she'll announce I'm currently appearing over at Mario's fine supper club.  Right over CBS she'll say that, Mario.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're full of shit.  You know that?  All bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just a vulgar word for PR. (placing an arm around him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mario, you can't hurt my feelings.  Even when I was a kid and they hurled certain invectives my way, it never bothered me.  Other kids would fall apart if anybody called them a fucking name.  Me, I just loved the attention!  'Shit-for- brains' -- that's what the bigger kids named me.  And I answered to it.  Hey, 'shit-for brains' reporting for duty.  Everybody loved me for that.  I could take abuse.  After a while, I kind of wore them down.  There was nothing more they could say to me.  So they stopped.  I kind of missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I even talked to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet your loving wife put you up to this.  She saw me pass by and she sent you out in the street.  But I don't hold it against you personally -- you still serve up superior veal chop. (entering phone booth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I got urgent business to conduct, Mario. He slides the booth closed in Mario's face. The frustrated restaurateur glares at him through the gla before giving up and walking off -- talking to himself as goes up the block. INSIDE THE BOOTH, Stu inserts his thirty-five cents and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mavis, sweet creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?  Do you think I have nothing to do but wait around for you to call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only a few minutes late, loveliest individual on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu, I'm so lonely.  When can I see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news in that arena.  Kelly goes into rehearsal as of Monday.  You know how dedicated she is.  By the time she gets back from dancing her ass off, she goes right to sleep.  We'll have both our days and certain nights.  Not to mention when they take the show on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four to five weeks -- minimum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should quit my job so we can be together full time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think if I have to give one more fucking manicure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how you met me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw a worse set of nails.  Bit right down to the quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm much better groomed since you've been looking after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Kelly remarked on it when I first met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could care less how you look.  She's only interested in pushing her own career.  Some wife you're stuck with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage is not without its compensations.  Do you imagine I could afford that apartment on what I'm earning?  Not with everybody cutting back on the publicity.  Not to mention a million college graduates coming into the profession trying to cut me out.  And one thing you can't expect from your clients is loyalty.  They get a couple of bad notices, they dump you.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't saying goodbye to you.  I was saying how the clients try to give you the wave off without even a month's notice. A conservative businessman now stands outside the booth waiting to use it.  He deliberately glances at his watch few times to demonstrate his impatience.  This bothers St who slides the booth open a crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Is your watch busted?  It's twenty after eleven and I'm gonna be occupied indefinitely with my transaction.  So get out of my face! He closes the booth up again and turns his back to the gentleman who gives up and departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, honey.  There will be no further interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must you always be calling me from some booth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On account of that phone records are regularly subpoenaed in divorce proceedings.  And I don't want some entry showing up on my cellular bill either.  She gets the mail.  She looks these items over.  Sometimes she even dials up a strange number to see who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she suspects something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only because her last husband, the choreographer, ran around on her.  She can't get that out of her head.  That's how she caught onto him.  The phone bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't developed much skill at holding a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a self-fulfilling prophecy is?  She was so sure I was going to find me a woman that she finally drove me back to you.  I thought I'd feel all guilty about it -- but I guess it hasn't kicked in yet. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, I wouldn't do anything to hurt her.  Basically, Kelly's a decent individual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about hurting me?  Like last time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurt?  You were glad to be rid of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while I was, 'til I took stock of what was around.  You're the lesser of many evils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's about the nicest thing you ever said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have it engraved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been up front with each other from the beginning.  Let's keep it that way.  How about a drink?  Say seven o'clock?  The Monkey Bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet me in front.  I don't like walking in there unescorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're great enough looking to be mistaken for one of those thousand dollar a night girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens all the time lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wear that short black number I bought you from Bendel's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?  I don't know if it's me or that dress you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good day.  Make plenty of tips.  And leave the whole evening open.  She thinks I've got Knicks tickets. He hangs up.  Then whips a tiny cellular phone out of his jacket pocket, flips it open and dials.  Someone answers the first ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into cellular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your boy Stuart.  When was the last time I called you for a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The column is already full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need one line.  Anybody you wanna say was seen dining out at Mario's Stromboli restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't hear so good?  I got no space for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's asking any favors?  I'm offering reciprocal information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when were you ever a reliable source?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out.  Tony award-winning producer Willie Beagle tossed his wife back into rehab again following her third attempt at diving off the terrace at their plush eighteen room residence at the San Remo.  I got it from the doorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it from their maid yesterday.  It's in the paper today.  Or don't you bother to read my shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, my intentions were entirely honorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drop your item in sometime next week.  If you promise not to call me for a month. He hangs up.  Stu looks pleased as he folds the cell phon and tucks it away. Then he starts to vacate the booth.  The phone rings.  An rings.  Curious, he picks up the receiver.  There's a voi on the other end of the line.  A DISTINCTIVE MALE VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think about leaving that booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay exactly where you are and listen carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a heavy day, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know better than to disobey me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who's watching you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love the gray suit.  That red and black tie makes a nice combination. Stu is taken back by the accurate description of his appa He looks around nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?  Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer than you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are any number of windows.  Check them out. Indeed that street corner is surrounded by high rise buildings and hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you had your little joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sufficiently amused.  Not yet.  We have more to talk about. Stu knows he should simply hang up but something tells hi not to.  Perhaps it's the strange tone of the man's voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor.  Call up somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's you I'm interested in.  You know how many people use that booth every day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than two-hundred people on average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you do?  Count them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do I have to do?  It's interesting watching people.  Trying to guess who they are.  And what they're up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you -- a shut-in of some kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might say that.  I can't go out.  I might be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's looking for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ex-wife.  What'd you do -- run out on child support?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of man do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, I could care less.  You had your fun.  Now goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not in your best interests to hang up on me.  That would make me angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that just too bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's ten million names in the phonebook.  Pester somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never talk to people I can't see.  I need to study their reactions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, bullshit artist, what am I doing right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scratching your forehead with your left hand.  Now you're brushing your hair back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, you got me in your scrutiny.  So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only I got nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you will.  You'll do a lot of talking before this conversation is over.  And it'll only end when I want it to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?  Well if you watch closely, you will see me hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I interest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I be interested in some creep who gets his jollies spying on strangers in phone booths?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not a stranger, Stu. The sound of his own name sends a chill through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who put you up to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were my very own selection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me in particular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're so afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!  What've I got to be afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just about everything.  You have so much to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you figure that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else would a man with a perfectly good cellular bother to make calls from a pay booth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made it mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a sudden I'm required to give explanations to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In explicit detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?  Some kind of candid camera gag?  Or like that thing on HBO where the cab driver is taping what goes on in the back seat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not showbusiness, my friend.  This is reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your reality.  Not mine, you lowlife fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu, you'll be made to suffer for your attitude, so let's dispense with the vulgarities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're threatening me!  Fuck you.  Could that be any clearer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're only making it easier for me to do you harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.  Right.  Can you see how I'm trembling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, this is a new one.  Fucking threatening calls in a goddam phone booth.  When are you going to start with the heavy breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the degenerate.  You are, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know anything about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Infinitely more than you know about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the number you dialed when you first entered the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm watching through a scope and I could clearly read the buttons you pushed.  I have another extension here by the window.  Shall I dial that same number back for you?  Would that convince you? Stu nervously cranes his neck, looking around at all the buildings that surround the street corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING up at thousands of windows.  The Voice could be coming from anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see who's on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already ringing.  I'll hold the receiver up so you can listen in. Stu can hear the beeping as the other line rings. Then Mavis' voice can be heard answering.  Stu listens helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who's really tight with your boyfriend -- who just called you from his favorite phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Stu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu?  Oh, I know him better than anyone.  What he does -- how he thinks.  How he lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu is listening in.  He knows what we're both saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu?  Is that true?  Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't feel like talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis!  Just hang up the goddam phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't hear you, Stu.  Only me. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis, I'm afraid Stu hasn't been totally honest with you.  But then he can't be honest with anyone, can he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?  To whom am I speaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never heard of me, Mavis.  He doesn't want you to know I exist.  He wishes I didn't exist.  But there isn't anything he can do about that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still there, Stu?  All you can do is listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis -- the guy is a fucking nutcase!  Hang the fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't want to.  She wants to know all about us.  Don't you, Mavis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did his wife put you up to this?  That bitch, Kelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, the bitch wife, Kelly.  My very next call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know my wife!  Don't tell him anything else. Outside the booth, a huge, heavy-set black woman in a too tight dress, now appears with the clear desire to use the phone.  Her name is FELICIA.  She taps on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you hurry it along? Stu ignores her and Felicia glares at him through the gla with hostility. Stu has no inclination to deal with anybody else.  He's t distracted by the madness happening over the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, Mavis?  Keep your big mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that any way to talk to a woman you love? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis, is he always that abusive to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting me all upset.  I don't know who you are or how you know all this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find out things -- from watching people and listening to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what is your relationship to Stu?  That's all I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer me, goddam it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well alright.  Stu and I are -- longtime companions.  A pair.  Two of a kind.  Closer than close.  Peas in a pod.  Spoons in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pervert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't believe a word of it.  It's all lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late, Stu.  She already believes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell that scumbag never to bother me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't care.  He'll still have me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not true.  I do care. From outside the booth, there's a louder rapping on the glass.  Felicia really wants in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get done in there, mister.  I got me an important call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit I will!  Finish up! She continues to rap on the glass as Stu tries to focus o the two-way phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me what you think of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he said about you.  Well, if Stu didn't have the balls to come out and tell you the truth, I felt it was my responsibility to clear the air.  Goodbye now, Mavis.  Thanks for your time. (the phone clicks off; we hear only a dial tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to you again, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You total asshole!  How could you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of females, that woman hovering outside the booth -- may as well tell her that you'll be on the line forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready for you to take out your cellular and phone home.  And this time, I'll listen in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no chance of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or should I call Kelly and make up something totally outrageous?  You must realize by now I have a vivid imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know our phone number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely sure?  I may have been watching you on a regular basis.  Keeping track of all the numbers I see you dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm supposed to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've put a great deal of preparation into this -- prior to actually saying hello.  Now do you want to dial 832-7165 -- or should

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: The sound of the actual number being spoken shocks him ev more than the earlier mention of his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try telling her the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't want to hurt Kelly.  She's always there for me.  It's just my nature to have a little 'strange' on the side.  It doesn't mean shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you still find it necessary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like having a beautiful home.  With everything you ever dreamed of.  But you still need that vacation now and then.  Some nice hotel room with a great view.  Maybe a pool.  Only you wouldn't want to spend more than a few days in any hotel.  Eventually, you want to go back to your home and all your stuff.  You're real glad to check out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly is home and Mavis is a hotel?  I'm sure they'll both appreciate that explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ruining my fucking life, you sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I warn you about calling me names?  It makes me vindictive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can you do to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't even begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not home.  She went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet she's back.  Now hold the cellular up where I can see it -- so I can be certain you don't misdial on me. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little higher and to your left.  Now I have it in perfect view.  Dial slowly. More violent rapping on the glass from the persistent bla lady outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got you a cell phone, how come you taking up the whole fucking booth!  This here's an emergency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another booth on the next block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's busted.  Every damn phone on Eighth Avenue is busted but this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not through!  Go in a restaurant or someplace, but get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna pull you out of that booth and snatch you ballheaded! She tries to pull open the sliding door to the booth but jams it shut, right on her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You assaulted my person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me hear from your lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hear alright.  I'm coming back.  And your ass better not be around. She stalks off obviously in search of assistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work, Stu.  Now let me see you dial.  Tuck the receiver under your chin and dial your remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing it. He punches in the digits.  The phone rings -- and rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you she was out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it ring. Then a girl's voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shepard residence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it close to the receiver so I can hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's taking you so long?  I thought we were having some lunch at Mario's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change of plan.  We're not eating in that dump any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Health Department gave them a 'C' rating -- that's how come.  Here I'm trying to put the place on the map and he fucks it all up with a major roach problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's disgusting.  Okay, I'll fix us a sandwich.  Where are you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in a phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?  The caller ID says you're on your cellular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're also in some phone booth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain that one, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only stepped in because the traffic was so loud outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well just hurry on back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're alone?  I hear somebody in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy in the next booth.  He's got a bad connection and he's hollering his fool head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got an answer for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu -- who was that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some person who phoned fifteen minutes ago -- just after you went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This total stranger rang up and told me to wait by the phone -- because you'd be calling me in a few minutes -- from a booth.  And I said what would he be doing in any phone booth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did this guy say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said you'd be making phone calls.  What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making calls is part of my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clients.  People.  Planting items like I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in a while one of them could be a woman.  I just called "Elaine's" and talked to her to see who was in there last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know exactly what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to start that shit again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could be wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you sound.  You don't sound like yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Who do I sound like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who's scared.  There's fear in your voice like I've never heard before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Stu?  Kelly agrees with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come back home.  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  In a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I want you here now.  In case he calls back, I don't want to answer again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should he call back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like he's going to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one that sounds frightened.  And of nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a nobody.  He knows about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not telling me all he said.  What are you holding back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't discuss it on the phone.  Just get over here! CLICK!  She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that to her?  She never did you any harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know?  Everybody does harm to somebody.  And then they try their best to forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe me -- but not her.  Whatever I've done, there's no reason to take it out on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose that's the only way I can get to you?  You claim you love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even love yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Kelly... I would never hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still you have to uphold your status as an honorary asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I've treated all my women decent.  I never laid a hand on any of them, even when provoked.  And I always let them down easy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ready to let Kelly go.  Maybe I never will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she dumps you first?  What's the odds she's already taken up with somebody?  One day soon you'll come home and find her gone along with the CD player and the VCR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna let you mind-fuck me all day!  That's it.  This call is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until I say it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens if I hang up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't really want to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to hear this!!!  What the fuck can you do about it -- up in your fucking high window with your goddam binoculars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never indicated I had binoculars.  I said I had a highly magnified telescopic image of you that brought you up so close I could see where you nicked yourself under the chin shaving this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- while you're at it, have a look up my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may very well do that, Stu.  In the meantime, think about what kind of device has a telescopic sight mounted on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You mean... like a rifle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-powered .30 calibre bolt action Remington 700 with a carbon one modification and a state of the art Henzholdt tactical sniperscope.  And you're in the cross hairs, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one way I can prove it to you.  Hang up the receiver and find out.  At this range, the exit wound ought to be about the size of a small tangerine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're just going to kill me for no reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For plenty of reasons!  Because you hung up.  For years I hated people hanging up on me.  Ex-girlfriends.  Women I didn't even know.  Prospective employers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get hung up on all the time.  You get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or else you don't.  I worked for months getting people to switch to MCI -- being insulted at and being hung up on hundreds of times a day.  The ones that cursed me out for invading their privacy never bothered me as much as those that clicked off without even bothering to reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why didn't you go after one of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you are one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I have worked in a boiler room myself peddling "Term Life."  I Would never be rude to a fellow salesperson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you feel it on you now?  The heat of it.  I'm moving the strike zone down to your stomach area.  Now I'm raising it up again.  Directly above the chest cavity -- sliding up to the forehead just above the left ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit -- I do feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me where I'm going with it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across my forehead -- now back where it was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm amazed how you can do that.  You're amazingly accurate. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know what you're thinking.  If I drop down on the floor of the booth and flatten myself out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes you are.  Can I crawl out using the booth as a shield?  Can I crawl to that Chrysler illegally parked only three or four feet away?  The shattering glass may cut me, but it'll only be superficial.  Otherwise, this lunatic will never let me out alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You will.  I know you will.  If I just cooperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it now?  Think and feel for the warm spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below the shoulder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remarkable how we're in tune.  You're doing far better than the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What others?  What do you mean? (no reply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said 'others!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you read about the Italian tourist shot dead ten days ago at the corner of Forty-fifth and Eighth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it on the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are we now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.  Forty-fifth and Eighth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do you remember about that killing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was gunned down.  And nobody was caught.  And they didn't even bother to take his wallet or his watch... or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know why.  It wasn't a robbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hung up -- so I disconnected him permanently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- don't do it to me.  You got no reason to do it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not looking to.  Tell me what you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to tell?  I'm in Public Relations.  They used to call us "flacks."  Now we're media consultants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plant items in the paper and on the tube.  More important sometimes, keep stuff out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What've you kept out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my people got nailed for indecent exposure.  I managed for the cops to use his real name instead of his stage name so nobody picked up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saved the little deviate's ass, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in major therapy now.  I swear he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must hang with some major celebrities.  Journalists, newscasters -- those types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real close with Larry King.  And the "Hard Copy" people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you get him down here?  Larry King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he want to come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you asked him to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes from Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who could you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wolf Blitzer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely no chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be offering them an exclusive newsbreak.  I'm talking about more than one homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't answer questions.  I ask them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta have the facts.  They might not believe me.  My record isn't too good when it comes to hard news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not considered a reliable source?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a divorce or separation, maybe.  Or who's gay, or who isn't gay any more.  I kind of specialize in that kind of material.  I mean I could probably get you Joe Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Cindy Adams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have a shot.  Are you familiar with Liz Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know her number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want I should call her?  How much can I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her you're in direct touch with a killer who's willing to speak honestly if she shows up here alone and without notifying the authorities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She usually likes to have a celebrity involved.  If you had an actor or a sports figure held prisoner instead of me, there'd be better odds she's come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then lie.  Pick a celebrity and put them in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see.  Who does she like?  Who couldn't be reached to deny it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm anxious to see you in action.  Don't keep me waiting. Stu uses his cellular again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dialing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you only get her service. (into cellular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi -- Stu Shepard.  Put me through.  I've got hard news for her.  I can only talk to her directly.  But say it regards -- Liza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liza?  That was imaginative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into cellular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't call back.  I'll have to lay in on somebody else.  Alright, but I can't hang on long. (to pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming on. (to cellular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz, hello.  Sure I'll make it brief.  Killing two weeks ago in the theatre district?  Turn out a sniper did the job.  Yeah, a sniper with a rifle.  Now he's got another victim lined up.  Not just your anonymous New Yorker, but Liza.  Now you can't call anybody or Ms.  Minelli's dead meat and so am I.  She's hostage in a phone booth right in the sniper's sights.  But he says he'll talk to you and let her walk.  I know it'll take balls to do this, but you're a fine and courageous newspaper woman... There's a click.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Hello? (to pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either she's on her way over or she doesn't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't particularly convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't really believe in what I was saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you don't really believe my Remington is pointed at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ninety percent sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least ninety-five percent, easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me erase all doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Don't shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control yourself, Stu.  Glance down at your chest.  What do you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.  A dot.  A fucking red dot. A tiny red dot now moves across Stu's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you've seen in the movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laser dot.  Just before some poor bastard always gets blown away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually a supporting player.  That lovely but by now generic special effect of the bullet piercing the forehead. The tiny red laser dot dances around Stu's chest and stom -- the jumps up and remains between his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This takes all the guesswork out of it.  You know exactly where to expect it before I even tighten my finger on the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tighten.  Don't even tickle that fucking finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Geraldo?  He's run his ass off to get in on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about the old Geraldo.  Look, I can try and reach cable NBC.  They're hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed.  I wanted to go first class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do a great job.  They'll haul a whole crew over to cover your surrender "live."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never expressed interest in giving myself up.  There are so many other phone booths in the city.  I'm just getting warmed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's entirely up to you.  Your choice.  I'm just trying to set you up with the proper communicator. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose Liza wasn't strong enough.  I should've said Madonna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're being creative. Outside the booth, the angry black woman has returned, bringing with her a gaudily dressed pimp named LEON who l like he means business.  He slams his fist against the gl nearly shattering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drag your baggy butt out of that booth.  We got business to conduct out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He been in there all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang up that receiver or I'll make you eat the fucking thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off or I'll call a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see one around here?  What you think I'm gonna be doing while you're waiting for a prowl car to get assigned?  I'm about to cut you a second asshole if you don't vacate those premises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got him a fucking cellular.  What's he need to be on our booth for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in your explanations even if you had any. He withdraws a switchblade knife from his pocket but does open it -- yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I flick this, I use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it worth your while to go away.  How much do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make me an offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty dollars.  It's all I've got in cash.  Take it and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're offering to rent my phone booth?  For how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  For as long as it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so special in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a genuine Rolex you've got on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man.  That's my good watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it's gonna take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then here.  Take the damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the thirty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it all. The pimp pockets the watch and the money.  But doesn't go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm satisfied.  But you still got to deal with Felicia here.  I believe you spoke harshly to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did her some injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An accident.  I'm sorry about that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man don't sound like he means it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree. (to Stu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you hang up a minute so we can discuss this matter at length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's long distance.  I can't lose the call -- I might not get them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to rip that fucking phone out of there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wouldn't be a good idea. (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you everything I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That pinky ring looks attractive.  Felicia might like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the ring, you've got the ring.  If I can get it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get it off you. Leon reaches in and grabs Stu's ring hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go of me!  It's coming loose.  There. (he tosses it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Felicia, with my deepest apologies.  Goodbye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's really going on in that booth -- that escapes the naked eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Talk.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your connection on the end of the line?  Or are you dealing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has nothing to do with drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be high on something to willingly divest yourself of your valuables -- just to maintain occupancy of a fucking phone booth that the local bums piss in every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it smelled for some reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you're ready to piss yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if the city provided decent public toilets, folks wouldn't relieve themselves in the subway stations and phone booths!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it up with the mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next thing you know you're gonna claim we mugged you -- took your billfold and watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you didn't.  It was a fair and equitable deal.  You had territorial rights to this booth and I paid a license fee.  Fair is fair.  Now leave me in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're alright? (to Felicia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't look well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of pale.  Even for a white man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaundice they calls it.  Probably advanced liver trouble. (to Stu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's cirrhosis, you better find yourself a twelve step program and quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your interest but I'm in perfect health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come his hand is shaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is cracking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit the sweat pouring off the sonofabitch.  That's one sick mother you started up with, Leon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  You're the one that brought me over and exposed me to all his germs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terminal, okay?  Now can I close the booth and continue my conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried now it might be catching.  All that money out of your sweaty pocket is probably crawling with some rare and incurable disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Give it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good's that?  We done touched it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well go wash your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now.  Own up to what you're carrying.  Is it some of that sexually transmitted shit?  Cause in that case, we can relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of you.  Now get out of my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we's being solicitous as to your health and you respond by heaping abuse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whip his arrogant ass. Leon reaches into the booth and grabs Stu's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch me and I'll throw up on you. At the suggestion, Leon lets go quickly. It looks like a stalemate.  Stu isn't vacating the booth Leon and his lady are reluctant to touch him further.  He does indeed look sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see what I'm up against here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to get rid of him for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think of something. Suddenly the red dot reappears on the forehead of the pim Leon doesn't realize it's there.  The hooker behind him h no way of seeing it.  But to Stu, there's no way to miss He reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God -- no. (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.  It's not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for my help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll handle it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not doing too well.  I can settle it in a fraction of a second.  Shall I demonstrate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (to Leon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your own safety, mister, just walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the man is turning aggressive... issuing threats upon my person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making this happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't hang up and step out, I'm about to topple this booth into the gutter with you inside it. Reluctant to touch Stu again, Leon assaults the booth its He begins shaking it violently -- trying to rip it from i foundation.  And the rickety booth is not too sturdy.  It starts rocking back and forth. Stu is thrown around inside it, barely keeping his footin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't my fault. (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that! But Leon continues rocking the booth.  It won't come loos so in frustration, he punches in a side pane of glass. The glass shatters all around Stu, who does his best to shield himself from the slivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy's insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one way to stop a mad dog.  Give me permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he forces you out of that booth, I've told you what to expect.  You or him, Stu. Leon is smashing other panes of glass now -- one after another -- as Stu cowers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cut yourself, honey. A crowd of derelicts and street people are now gathering watch the out of control pimp take out his wrath on the b and its occupant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like the fucker is comin' loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shove it out into the oncoming traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you bet the bus could knock that fifty feet? The booth is being decimated but Stu hangs onto the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with heavy static)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking up.  We're about to be cut off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That counts as a hang-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It can't.  That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can still make him stop.  Say the word.  Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Stu sees the red dot reappear on Leon's chest as he conti to barrage the booth with punches and kicks. Then Leon recoils, staggers a step backward.  He doesn't realize he's been shot. There's been no sound of gunfire.  Perhaps a silencer was used -- or the downtown traffic drowned out the solitary discharge. Leon looks confused at first.  His ladyfriend has no idea he's wounded -- neither do the derelicts and street peopl who've assembled on the corner. Even Stu isn't sure -- until the blood starts oozing from wound on the pimp's chest -- staining his yellow vest. He isn't assaulting the booth anymore.  He's trying to ke his balance.  He slumps forward, hanging onto the booth f support -- only a few inches from Stu's face.  The blood down the side of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said 'yes.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said 'Yes, I can hear you.'  Not 'Yes -- kill the motherfucker!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to renege on it.  I was following orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're twisting it all around.  I didn't do this! Meanwhile, Leon leans upright against the booth.  Then hi legs cave in and he begins to slide to his knees. Felicia runs up beside him.  She sees the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned you not to cut yourself. (to crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at all that blood.  He must've hit an artery. She screams as Leon topples backwards onto the pavement. his chest wound is evident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.  What is that?  Talk to me!  What happened? The crowd tightens around the fallen body.  Street people are fascinated but not shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunshot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sucking chest wound right over the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody call an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the meatwagon.  He's fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shut the fuck up! Her focus turns to Stu in the battered phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all saw it!  He shot my man without no provocation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Pumped one right into him at close range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I?  I don't even have a gun.  Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody get the fuck back!  They shoot one -- then they shoot everybody in sight!  Kill all the fucking witnesses! The crowd disperses to doorways and around the corner -- of immediate range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back.  You've got to see -- I'm not armed. Only Felicia remains, leaning over the pimp's body, stari helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang up and dial 911.  Get a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hang up.  That's what this is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna stand there and let him die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes out cellular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can use this. (he dials)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency.  Yes.  There's been a shooting at Forty-fifth and Eighth  -- on the corner.  A man is down.  What's the difference who I am?  I don't want to be involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.  He's the shooter.  You're talking to the shooter. Stu quickly disconnects the cellular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead -- make a fucking run for it.  I hope they gun you down -- like you did him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going anyplace.  I'm staying right here in this booth. (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you give me permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're attracting a lot of attention.  I suppose when the police get there, you'll accuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's up to you.  But any mention of me will not be appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't even get to finish your sentence.  Oh look, that little red dot is dancing around all over you again.  You saw how quickly it can happen.  And how accurate I can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't blame me -- I'm not armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's going to believe that?  With all those witnesses to the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can see with their own eyes. Not far away, we hear the BLAST of POLICE SIRENS drawing closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember to leave me out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll put the proper spin on it.  Isn't that your specialty?  Feeding the public a story that may not have a shred of truth -- and making it totally believable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a story.  This is real.  This is murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd only dealt with the man reasonably, shown him some respect, this might not have been necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him my money, my watch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not your respect.  Which is what he required of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a fucking thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he's a fucking dead thief.  Do you feel better about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel a bit guilty.  This is all your doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're being disrespectful of me.  You never learn.  Your job is to deal with people -- but you're not good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not taking any more criticism from some lunatic sniper who gets his kicks killing strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep insisting I'm a stranger.  Probably because you don't recognize the voice.  But there are cheap electronic devices available that disguise the voice.  I might not even be a man.  I might be one of those many women you've almost totally forgotten.  One who doesn't forgive easily.  One who wants to watch you squirm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a man.  I know you're a man.  Women don't kill with telescopic rifles.  They stab you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound so sure of that.  But you've never provoked any man as much as have the women in your life.  And so many of them, Stu. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even remember their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got no time to rehash my whole life.  Oh my God!  The cops are here. Police cars are pulling up on all sides of Eighth Avenue. Traffic has suddenly been shut down.  Prowl cars have now blocked the streets. PRODUCTION NOTE: Everything is seen from Stu's perspectiv without intercuts. Half a dozen cops now emerge and approach with drawn guns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him -- in the booth.  He's got a gun! As she hurls accusations, she's lugging Leon's lifeless b out into the gutter into the center of Eighth Avenue. It's a bright afternoon.  In the distance, we hear the maddening HONKING of uptown traffic that is now being rerouted, creating a huge bottleneck and raising the ange irate motorists and bus drivers whose horns provide their simplest form of protest.  It's a discordant concert that echoes the confusion and frustration which Stu now feels. As the cops surround the booth -- at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into bullhorn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw down your weapon and come out with your hands raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ordering me to come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see that.  Ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they open fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They probably won't.  Look across on the east side of the street.  Do you see the tourist with the home video camera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distant crowd gathering on the opposite west side corne behind the police cars.  Some tourist is capturing the ev on video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to keep the police on their best behavior.  So long as you don't take what could be interpreted as hostile action, you'll be safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this safe?  Six cops with guns pointed my way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to reduce them to three -- or two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely no more shooting.  Now is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can always change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with bullhorn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the drill.  Hands clasped behind the back of your neck -- moving slowly -- step out of the booth.  If we see any sign of a weapon, we will respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't, because there isn't any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bullhorn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I repeat.  Raise your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  I'm on a phone call. Now a black POLICE CAPTAIN arrives and takes full command the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have thirty seconds to comply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  I'm busy.  Come back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Stu. The cops take cover behind parked cars, keeping Stu clear in their sights.  He has no place to hide.  He's in the battered phone booth in plain view from all sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been given an order. The Sergeant slides up beside the Captain to confer. PRODUCTION NOTE: We remain in LONG SHOT of the cops -- al from Stu's POV.  But we can hear their voices and all tha said as if they were in close up.  It has an odd, unreal distancing effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dealing with a mental case.  He's looking for us to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's not getting his wish. In the center of the street, an ambulance pulls up and a of medics jump out.  They rush to Leon's body.  (Again we hear their voices close, even though visually they are fa off.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me he's gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step aside.  Let us look at him. The medics push her aside -- then examine the victim.  He DOA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing we can do.  Don't touch the body.  They'll need it to mark the crime scene. Far across the street, the Captain confers with his subordinates.  They are small figures on the screen but w hear them sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same corner as two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's more than a coincidence.  Cover me.  I need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got your vest on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? The Captain steps out of cover and boldly approaches the phone booth.  He stops cautiously about fifteen feet away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.  I need to know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can.  My name's Ramey.  Captain Ed Ramey.  What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't want to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you need a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him you've already got a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a friend, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that who you're talking to on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When somebody gets shot, it becomes my business.  Let's not have anybody else killed.  I want to hear your side of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got no side of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Stu.  I've got him fixed right in my sights.  I won't let him hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has this happened to you before?  The need to hurt someone?  To put a bullet in them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't believe anything I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't shoot anybody.  I'm not armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  I don't believe you.  What's that bulge in your pants pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That?  That's my cellular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cellular?  Then what are you doing in a phone booth making calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't reach for it, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how can I show it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to see it.  I know what's there.  All these witnesses saw you use it on him. From behind a parked car, a HOMELESS PERSON calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hollers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight! Another DERELICT, crouched in a doorway, joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  Shot him down like a dog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all lying.  Nobody saw it because it didn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man is dead but it didn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not on account of me!  This is like some bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're walking through a bad dream and you can't wake up.  Do you want to wake up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in this dream, you killed that man.  He was bothering you so you iced him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell him, Stu.  Or it'll be the last thing he ever hears.  His blood will be on your hands.
