dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ramey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you saw it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the closest one to him.  You must've seen who did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to be honest with each other, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm losing patience with this cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm handling this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you keep talking to on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.  My psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, Stu.  You're getting good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this doctor's name?  It's important we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says not to tell you.  It's privileged information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn good reply.  Now you're having fun.  Admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing it so close to the edge.  I'll bet you've never felt so alive.  That's how I feel when I look through the sight and select somebody. The Captain begins advancing a few steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I respect your right to privacy.  I've been to therapy myself.  The department provides it.  I know it's not good form for a cop to be admitting that, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him not to come any closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop right there.  Back up a few steps.  Back where you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it makes you more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to read you your rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to read me my rights and stop asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al least tell me your first name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my right not to have any name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No gun and no name.  You're a highly underprivileged person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demand a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get me a lawyer, too.  I want a lawyer brought down here to negotiate my surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant, Stu.  Keep winging it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be hard to find a lawyer willing to risk his life.  But if you hand over the gun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I when you won't let me take it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it out for you -- as soon as you exit the booth with your hands raised and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're back to that again.  It's always "Get out of the booth.'  'You can't stay in the booth.'  Well, I like it in the fucking booth.  It's my whole world now.  It's my booth and I'm never coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not about to force you because there could be a miscalculation and then we'd never find out why this happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it so important to know?  The guy is dead.  Isn't that enough?  Knowing isn't going to make him alive again.  So who gives a fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what makes the job interesting.  Finding out why.  Something drove you to do this.  You didn't go out today expecting this to happen.  It was a nice day.  You were out for a walk.  And then suddenly it all changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I wanted was to make a phone call.  One lousy phone call for thirty-five fucking cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, Stu.  Don't volunteer too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some bad news on that call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something that pushed you over the edge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've been falling ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you hit bottom, you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your safety net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I tell you what you want to know -- you'll die, too. Something about the implied threat sends a chill through Captain Ramey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain's head as seen through a telescopic sight. Ramey could be dead in an instant. PRODUCTION NOTE: The only time we deviate from Stu's perspective is when we see the sniper's POV through his scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the detective fifteen feet away. Ramey decides to back off momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go see about that lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a good idea. The Captain withdraws back across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lucky.  I had him centered in my cross hairs.  I really had to restrain myself. We hear the approach of a helicopter. Stu peers up ward as not one but two choppers appear abov the tall buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the police.  It's the media.  You're news, Stuart. The helicopters circle above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never gotten this much press for any of your clients.  I'm making you a famous person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just hoping for coverage of me dying in the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their presence is putting the police on their continued best behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those cops are just looking for any excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't give them one. Then, as if on cue, Stu's cellular phone in his pocket st ringing. But he can't allows himself to reach for it.  To do so mi cause the police to believe he was trying to draw his gun It rings quietly -- virtually inaudible outside the booth Drowned out by the traffic horns, the static from the pol radios and the newly introduced sound of television helicopters circling over Eighth Avenue taking video cove of the event below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who could it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly.  She was worried about me. Stu is afraid to reach in his pocket lest the cops think going for a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she's seen this on television.  It must be on every channel by now.  Breaking news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't watch daytime TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the neighbors could've alerted her. The cell phone keeps ringing, almost drowned out by the s of helicopters circling overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you saying this?  You want me to reach in my pocket so you can see them open fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an unwarranted accusation and very unbecoming in light of the good advice I've given in the past.  Have I ever steered you wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God -- how I'd love to hear her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might even be worth it.  She's insistent, isn't she? The cellular won't stop ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she knows I'm in trouble, she won't give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably glued to the TV by now.  I'm watching coverage on two stations now.  Channel surfing. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there you are on two and four and five.  Not any decent angles on you, though, stuck inside there. The cell phone continues beeping until the sound of it is maddening.  Stu is still afraid to reach for it and provi the cops with an excuse to open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you'd take one or two steps outside and look up, I think they could get a clear picture of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said I'm not allowed to leave the booth. Finally the cell phone stops ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be willing to bend the rules and let you enjoy your moment of fame.  Set the phone down without hanging up... and take a step or two outside.  Just for a minute.  Then come straight back in or I'll be forced to provide 'live' coverage that should rival the historic Zapruder footage. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like an exploding head to excite viewer interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.  I'll stay where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was only a suggestion.  Since you're convinced I'm going to plug you anyway, it can't matter much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you shoot me, you give yourself away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even without a muffler, they'd never hear the report with all this noise.  Afterwards, it'd take them a good ten minutes to realize you weren't plugged by some overzealous officer.  Then they'll blame the media for inciting a crackpot vigilante to come down here and do the SWAT team's job for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expected them to come.  You had this all worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write the scenario and you all play your parts -- as directed. The damned cell phone starts beeping again.  Stu fights t temptation to grab for it and hear Kelly's voice for one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Kelly.  What she must be going through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell her how you feel about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never get the words out.  Not with fifteen or twenty rounds in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be certain they'd fire.  They'd see it was only a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't wait to see. The cellular ringing continues jangling Stu's nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't she hang up? Then Stu notices something in the crowd gathering far acr the street behind the police barricades.  Countless faces rubbernecking, probably hoping to see some display of violence that would end with him face down dead on the pavement. And in the midst of them -- one face familiar to him.  A female, quite pretty... even in tears.  It's Kelly.  (We her only in LONG SHOT -- a distant figure in bright green jacket that makes her stand out from the crowd.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her!  She's not calling me.  She's over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde girl in the green jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't miss her.  Very attractive, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must've heard all the commotion and come downstairs. The cellular is still ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's somebody else who knows my cell number. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You continue to impress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it so important that they kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's how I win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time you won't.  If you want me dead, you'll have to do it yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way I can't lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all a game to you -- because you're incapable of feelings.  You're not even human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pride myself on that.  What's so great about being human?  It's the lowest form of life on this planet and I've taken it upon myself to thin the herd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quit.  I'm not answering back any more.  I won't hang up but I'm not playing. There's silence now between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu?  Stu, don't be that way.  You're taking the pleasure out of it. Stu doesn't take the bait.  He remains absolutely silent. A stalemate has been reached.

dialogues.speaker: WE RACK FOCUS ACROSS THE STREET TO THE POLICE
dialogues.text: clustered behind an emergency vehicle.  The Sergeant brin civilian to meet Captain Ramey of the SWAT unit.  The newcomer wears coveralls stenciled "AT&T."  (Although are very far away, we hear their voices close up as they into sharper focus.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here's Helfand, of New York Telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got the number of that booth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tap into that call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not without a warrant.  You could be violating this psycho's civil rights.  Especially if he's on the line with his fucking psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  I don't want to blow this on a technicality.  Tracing the call isn't any violation, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as we don't listen in. We remain in LONG SHOT of the POLICE as they continue in heated conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Helfand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we've got to know who he's talking to and their current location.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I can handle.  As long as they keep the circuit open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the number and an address to go with it. Helfand rushes off.  At the corner, we can glimpse him entering a phone company utility truck parked on Forty-Fi Street.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS BACK TO PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Stu remains tight lipped and silent, refusing to give his tormentor the conversation he so craves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart, my friend.  Do you want to see how close I can come without actually hitting you? Stu resists pleading because he knows his silence is more powerful. There's no glass in the left side of the booth since the Leon smashed it all out. Nothing to shatter when the sniper squeezes off his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I call attention to the yellow pages? The frayed yellow phonebook dangling from a chain under t telephone shudders under the impact of a direct hit. There's been no sound of a gunshot, but the damage is the to behold. Stu reaches for the phonebook. There's a bullet hole straight through it.  Pieces of the calibre slug have shattered into many tiny fragments and imbedded between the pages, half-way through the thick volume. Stu pries pieces out of the pages of the directory.  He l at them in the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollow points are designed to break up on impact.  It would've behaved differently if it had pierced your soft flesh.  The pieces would've bounced around looking for a way out.  That's where the real damage occurs -- finding an exit -- deflecting off all that bone... Stu wants to shout "STOP," but restrains himself.  Not talking gives him some degree of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still the silent treatment?  My father used to dish that out when he chose to punish me.  Not a word spoken -- one time for over a month.  I'd try and goad him to acknowledge I existed, but he stared right through me.  You're bringing back unhappy childhood, Stu.  That's not wise. Stu still declines to answer.  His silence seems his only weapon.  He tosses the bullet fragments out of the booth the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you're ignoring me, I'll focus on someone else. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she is -- nice and sharp.  I can see the two little punctures in each earlobe and my God, what kind of a girl would have her nostril pierced? Stu realizes the sniper now has Kelly in his sights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?  Louder, Stu.  We must have a bad connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't expect her to show up here.  But since she has -- I'll improvise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.  Please don't.  I'm sorry.  I'm talking to you again.  I'll talk all you want!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bad dye job.  The black roots are growing in and it makes her look cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've screwed up her life enough already.  Please don't hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't necessarily have to kill her.  I could be persuaded to settle for a reasonable mutilation. Which part of her displeases you most?  If she turns a bit more in profile, I'm accurate enough to remove the tip of her unpleasantly protruding nose.  It's just cartilage.  Any decent cosmetic surgeon will have her looking better than ever.

dialogues.speaker: FOCUS SHIFTS TO KELLY
dialogues.text: in the crowd.  Distant yet distinct amongst the curious onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: AS SEEN THROUGH CROSS HAIRS OF TELESCOPIC SIGHT
dialogues.text: following her as she forces her way through the crowd tow the police officers. Her face virtually fills the screen. PRODUCTION NOTE: The only time we deviate from Stu and hi POV is when we see the sniper's own POV through his telescopic sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can see her talking to the police now.  She's identifying herself as your wife.  They're very interested in who you are.  They're taking her over to see the officer in charge.  What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the cross hairs of the sniperscope, we can see Ke conversing with Captain Ramey.  She's in a state of compl agitation.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: half leaning out of the booth, staring at his wife and th cops in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS TO THEM --
dialogues.text: and suddenly we can hear them clearly in spite of the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean psychiatrist?  He doesn't see any psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who'd your husband be talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some guy that called the house this morning and said weird stuff to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu seems to be checking things out with this person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't got many friends -- I can tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remain here, please.  We may need you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't hurt him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best not to. Kelly is left alone as the Captain returns to their comma center. Kelly is once again a solitary target.  She could be pick off without attracting undue attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't even feel it when it happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't distract me.  Now's the time to be absolutely still.  I have to hold my breath as I squeeze gently --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I'm hanging up.  That's it. Stu hangs up the receiver.  He disconnects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police as they react.  We see a flurry of activity ac the street.  Voices become clear as focus shifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  He hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they already traced it.  Anyhow, it doesn't matter.  Looks like he's coming out.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS BACK TO STU --
dialogues.text: slowly stepping out of the booth.  His hands are raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've giving myself up.  Take me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First the gun.  We want to see you toss away your weapon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze where you are!  Turn around and keep those hands clasped. (signals the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him. The SWAT OFFICERS in protective gear now step out of cove and fan out as they approach the booth.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHTER ON STU
dialogues.text: He's just outside the booth -- expecting to feel the snip bullet go through him at any moment. Then the pay phone starts ringing. The sniper is calling back.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS AGAIN
dialogues.text: to the police. All the cops react.  Particularly the Captain and the Sergeant.  Their voices seem close up when they sharpen i focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on with these fucking phone calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your fire.  Let him answer it. The SWAT team backs up but maintain their aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them talk.  He's not going anywhere. (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going back inside the booth. Indeed we see Stu re-enter the battered phone booth and p up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? A strange voice begins chattering away in Spanish.  Total unintelligible to Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the wrong number.  Hang up. The voice, probably a Puerto Rican gentleman, rattles on Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong number.  Wrong number. Then the voice on the phone suddenly alters the Hispanic accent.  It is the now familiar tone of his tormentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, relax, Stu.  Only yanking your chain.  Now can we start over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those cops won't wait much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can they do?  They can't afford to just shoot you like I can.  Not with so much media coverage.  Not unless you make some stupid aggressive move. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ABC Mobile Unit just rolled up. Across the street, Stu can see various TV units from loca stations setting up cameras on roofs of trucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you look at that?  I must be going out over the network.  Bet they're pre-empting usual programming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just think -- if you survive this, your trial will be televised.  And you can try and make the world believe I ever existed.  I'd be your only defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are they gonna prove that I killed anybody when there's no gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll plant one.  The police aren't above that -- when they're desperate to convict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  No gun and I walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I took that into account?  Am I a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I considered every eventuality?  I knew they'd come and cordon off the block. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that there'd have to be a gun someplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small booth, Stu.  Have you checked every inch of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up and down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.  Why don't you reach up there and lift the plastic sheet -- and feel around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they see me reach for something, they could open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could.  But you have to know if it's there.  Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I totally don't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a narrow space, tucked just to the left of the fluorescent bulb.  You can almost see it outlined if you look closely. Stu peers upward at the clouded plastic, now stained and dirty.  There are shadows of objects above in the shallow area around the light fixture that automatically goes on the door to the phone booth is tightly closed. Stu opens and closes the door a few times, watching the l click on -- watching the shadows around the light. Could that be an accumulation of dirt, dust, or dead inse Or could something be stashed up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.  I know about ballistics.  The slug in that dead guy came from your rifle, not any handgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw how hollow points splinter on impact.  There's nothing much for ballistics to match to.  The same make .30 calibre bullets are in that handgun.  The prosecution rests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no gun up there.  I don't see a damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide your finger up under the plastic and you'll feel the cold metal surface.  There are four rounds left in it.  Should you decide to shoot your way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never shoot anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could shoot me, Stu.  You'd do that in a minute if you could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd fucking love it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're speaking from the heart.  Come on, just lift the partition a few inches and feel what's there for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting my fingerprints on your fucking weapon.  What about powder residue?  How are they going to explain that to a jury?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that'll matter with so many eye witnesses? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it... or should I re-focus my attention on Kelly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You carefully distracted me from her before and I let you get away with it.  But if you're not going to play fairly -- (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she is again.  So close I feel like I could touch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then mind me when I speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look!  I'm reaching up with my left hand.  I'm pushing against the partition.  It's giving.  I'm feeling around with my fingertips.  It's filthy up there.

dialogues.speaker: STU'S FINGERS
dialogues.text: feel about inside the shallow space.  The shriveled remai of dead flies -- a layer of dust -- and then a .30 handgu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm -- touching something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the finest handguns Remington makes.  Lightweight, efficient and highly accurate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not picking it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now.  But eventually... Stu lowers his hand, still empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're getting there.  It wouldn't take much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could pull the gun down, shove it in your own mouth and jerk the trigger.  That's another option.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To please me.  And ensure that nothing happens to Kelly.  I don't necessarily have to deal with her today in the midst of a crowd of cops.  I can take her out any time I like.  When she goes to pull down her blinds at night or when she walks the dog first thing in the morning.  What is it -- a Jack Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I know you can do it.  But don't talk about that.  Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather see you remembered as the gallant gunman who tried to shoot his way past an army of police -- than as a coward who sucked the barrel.  I'm doing your PR for you.  Creating a final image that'll endure.  The outraged New Yorker who was pushed too far.  When some lowlife street person tries to invade his territory, he retaliated.  And when the forces of the law closed in, he was defiant... to the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that nerdy sonofabitch who blew those three wiseass kids away on the subway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Nobody minded that he was a sicko.  He was living out a New Yorker's pet fantasy.  Can you remember that movie where Peter Finch started screaming 'I'm not taking it anymore!'  And everybody picked up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not taking it anymore.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was it.  Poor Finch got himself an Oscar for that.  But he was dead by then.  I mean he really died.  Maybe playing that part took too much out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I'm not taking it anymore.'  'I'm not taking it anymore.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way!  Psyche yourself up.  Everybody respects a man who fights back, even if he goes a little berserk in the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighting back.  That's what it's about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly!  We all understand the poor schmuck that gets laid off and comes back and shoots all his bosses.  We all thought of doing that.  But only he had the balls.  The terminally ill husband who gets his policy canceled and machine guns the insurance company offices.  Maybe somebody will finally get the message.  You can fuck human beings over only for so long before they come back at you.  I'm still holding on Kelly and she looks very concerned.  I could relieve all that anguish in a fraction of a second.  Shall I? Stu is hearing these words but thinking only of what the on the line has done to him.  His turn has come to fight back.  He has an idea. If the sniper is focused on Kelly, he can't be watching S Turning his back to the police, Stu slowly sinks to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my knees begging you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up, Stu.  You're embarrassing yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu now down on his knees in the booth.  He's curled up almost into a fetal position. By doing so, he hopes to hide the fact that he's reaching into his pants pocket and pulling out his cellular phone. He half expects to hear a shot ring out either from the sniper or the cops.  But nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu -- I want you back on your feet facing me.  So you can see what I'm going to do to her. Stu ignores the command.  He's quickly dialing. 911. He's calling police emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stu seen through the cross hairs of the sniperscope, crouched, doubled up at the foot of the booth.  But the c phone is hidden in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a man, Stuart.  Don't let them see you like this.  You're an embarrassment to me.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: with Stu still kneeling.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS
dialogues.text: to police across the street as their voices become clear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening to transmission)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer on east side of the street reports subject removed a dark metallic object from his pocket.  We better move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold all fire until you actually identify a weapon.  We're doing this on fucking TV!

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS BACK TO
dialogues.text: crouched forward.  The pay phone receiver dangles just ab his head.  The cellular remains cupped in his hand. Stu never lifts the cell phone.  He keeps the palm of his hand over the speaker of the phone to muffle any sound fr the other end. It rings and finally someone answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police.  Is this an emergency?  Hello?  Is someone on the line? But Stu addresses himself loudly to the pay phone which h now grips in his other hand.  Hoping that his words will picked up by the emergency operator listening via the cellular.  To help in this regard, he reaches back and sl the door to the booth tightly closed. He pretends to be talking to the sniper but his words are meant for the 911 operator to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made your point.  Who's going to believe I've got a sniper with a telescopic sight holding me in a fucking phone booth at 45th and 8th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took you a while to believe it yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd put a bullet in that Captain Ramey, it would've been a different story -- but you were too wise to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you do it for me?  Wave the old captain back over and get him nice and close and then use the handgun on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?  You could pick off any of those cops from your window up there.  Like you did that pimp.  And that tourist last week.  But this time you want me to do your killing for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you will!  To save Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: CELL PHONE
dialogues.text: cupped in Stu's hand and held low.  Can they hear him on other end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled, almost inaudible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you speak up, sir?  What is your name? Stu is concerned that the sniper might hear the voice of emergency operator.  He sets the cell phone down flat on floor of the booth facing upward.  He puts his foot over receiving end to muffle the incoming voice.  Then he stan up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better, Stu.  Now turn around so I can see you. Stu talks close into the pay phone receiver now.  But kee his voice raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This booth.  It's my whole world -- shrunk down to four feet by three feet.  Not much bigger than the size of a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can put handles on the booth and bury you in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I saw you put that bullet into that black dude, I knew you'd never let me out of this phone booth alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting my time.  Reach up and take the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering upward, squinting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see you first.  What harm can that do you?  You're in one of those windows.  I've got to know which one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being so far, I could never identify you.  I don't even want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry that I'd try to point you out.  You'd shut me up with one of your .30 calibre hollow points before I could even raise a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does it matter so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see that you exist.  Like God exists.  It's not enough to believe.  You want to see him -- just once -- even at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you'd take the gun down.  And use it.  We have a deal on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show yourself to me and I'll take the gun down.  I swear. There's a pause as the sniper mulls it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to make deals.  And you're irritating me by trying to negotiate.  God doesn't have to prove anything.  He just strikes you down when he gets in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!  I won't ask to see you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad that's settled.  But look who else has showed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess she saw the coverage on TV and just couldn't keep away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'hotel' just arrived.  And a very beautiful little hotel she is.  Actually, I'd classify her as more of a motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis?  I don't see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's too far back behind the police line.  But I've got a fine shot at her from up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know what she looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in an enviable position now, Stu.  You get to choose between them.  Tell me which one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which will it be?  Kelly or Mavis?  Or should I simply select one?

dialogues.speaker: THE CELL PHONE
dialogues.text: lying face up on the floor of the booth.  Is anybody listening?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO STU
dialogues.text: Stu looks down at the cellular.  He has no way of knowing the police operator can hear any of his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need time to think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be more in touch with your feelings.  You said you love Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm doing you a favor putting you out of the way of temptation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't Mavis' fault.  It was all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take the third option.  Reach above you and pick up the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll leave them both alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be much point in harming them without you around to impress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need one minute.  One last minute, please.  Can you give me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're going to say your prayers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE
dialogues.text: assembled on the opposite side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should've traced the fucking call by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening on transmitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something else coming in.  A 911 operator says your name was mentioned by somebody that's still on the line.  Somebody talking about a phone booth.  And a sniper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patch me through.  Hello, this is Captain Edward Ramey.  What about that call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line is still open.  It's originating from a booth at 45th and 8th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're there!  Can you play me back your recording of the entire call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't replay the tape while it's still running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then switch to another machine and play back what you've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful faint.  He's not talking directly into the receiver. Ramey begins to listen.  We hear snatches of Stu's call picking up words which are at times incomprehensible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Who's going to believe I've got a sniper with a telescopic sight holding me in some fucking phone booth...' The uniformed TELEPHONE TECHNICIAN now joins Ramey and th Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got what you wanted.  The call's coming from up the street.  The Hotel Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that easy.  Electronic switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sergeant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move your SWAT units to the hotel.  No... wait.  Any movement will alert the sniper.  If he sees any of us withdraw, he may panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another SWAT unit on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intercept them.  Divert them to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send them in from the Forty-third Street side.  I don't want any activity the sniper might catch sight of.  He's probably high up and facing that booth.  He's got to continue to believe our full attention is focused on the man inside -- whoever the hell that poor bastard is. (to emergency operator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello 911 operator, I missed some of that.  Run it halfway back and repeat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '... Like you did that pimp.  And that tourist last week.  But this time you want me to do the killing for you...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... he's a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police seem all excited about something, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they?  I wasn't looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait any longer.  Say amen, then reach up for the gun.  When your hand comes down, I want to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For once, be brave.  Surprise yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shaking all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys in combat situations even shit their pants.  But they follow orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as the cops see a gun, they'll open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'd advise you to fire first. Stu's arm goes up in a supreme act of willpower. His fingers run along the two clouded plastic sheets that cover the roof of the booth.  It raises up easily at the middle where two sheets join.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The space between the roof of the booth and the sheets of clouded plastic.  We see the fluorescent lighting fixture covered with dust.  The solitary object -- a cruel-lookin weapon. Now Stu's fingertips protrude into the small space.  He touches the gun, brushes back and forth, feeling the roughness of the grip.

dialogues.speaker: STU'S FACE
dialogues.text: as below he continues to hesitate -- it's agony -- The sweat pours down his forehead and his eyes are squeez tightly shut.  He can already imagine the police bullets tearing into him. A POLICE SNIPER IS MOVING INTO POSITION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into transmitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the word.

dialogues.speaker: RACK BACK TO STU
dialogues.text: His arm still raised.  He hasn't brought it down with the in it.  Not yet.  He holds the pay phone receiver jammed against his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard part's over.  Drop your arm and point it like you'd point your finger and squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You do it.  If you want me dead, then fucking murder me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must I keep invoking some poor girl's name every time we come to an impasse?  I'm focused back on Kelly again.  You're obviously not willing to trade your life for hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am!  I'm doing it! He pulls the handgun down into full view.  Curiously, the police do not open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!  You see it?  They all see it. He waves the gun so nobody can miss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?  Damn you!! He drops the receiver and steps halfway out of the booth. Still the cops do not open fire. Then Stu starts shooting. Not at the police, but at the high rise buildings across street. At the thousands of windows that look down upon him. He gets off two shots before a solitary rifle shot rings in response.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS TO THE POLICE SNIPER
dialogues.text: He has fired.

dialogues.speaker: STU
dialogues.text: The remaining glass on the south side of the booth shatte Stu tumbles forward, sprawling out of the booth onto the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: RACK FOCUS TO KELLY
dialogues.text: She screams, tries to break through but cops restrain her

dialogues.speaker: DANGLING RECEIVER
dialogues.text: as it sways back and forth.  From it, we hear the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for such an interesting afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: SWAYING PHONE.
dialogues.text: A wooden door being battered open.  A few incomprehensibl shouts as a SWAT TEAM dashes in.  Stu's stalling for time paid off. THE SOUND OF A BARRAGE OF GUNFIRE. THE SOUND OF A MUFFLED SCREAM. The police have broken in on Stu's tormentor and there ha been a rapid exchange of shots. A HAND reaches into the booth and grabs the receiver. ANGLE WIDENS as Ramey places it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  This is Captain Ramey.  Somebody talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  We took him out, Captain.  Nobody else got hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Critical.  The sonofabitch took two.  Probably won't survive the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a statement from him.  I'll be right over. He drops the receiver so that it dangles again. CAMERA FOLLOWS RAMEY to where Stu lies surrounded by cops medics.  He's stunned, but very much alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to sit up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneeling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubber bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have one hell of a nasty welt.  Busted rib.  Maybe a permanent scar there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't hurt much more if you really shot me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody was going to and we thought it may as well be us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure as hell did.  Thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be giving him a hypo for the pain.  It'll put him out for a while. Kelly is now brought over by a female cop.  She drops to knees beside Stu and tries to embrace him.  The medics restrain her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  I'm not really shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so afraid.  I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so, too.  But we're going to be alright.  Both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember how you swore up and down you'd get me on TV?  Well, you did.  I already got interviewed on Fox and Channel Eleven and they even want me on A.M. America tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you didn't think I could deliver on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please let go of him, Miss? A gurney is wheeled over from a police ambulance.  The me is about to administer the hypo but Stu pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No hypo.  I want to see him first. The medics are now ready to lift Stu onto the gurney and him off.  But Stu struggles against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  The guy's dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I've gotta talk to him.  Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can ride with him in the ambulance. The woman cop escorts Kelly to the waiting ambulance. Ramey meanwhile tries to resume contact with the SWAT tea inside the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ramey.  Over.  This is Ramey.  Ten-Four. There's nothing but static, mixed up feedback and multipl garbled voices on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  Get everybody off this wavelength. He crosses back to the phone booth -- picks up the dangli receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Hello!  Pick up!  Yeah, it's Ramey again.  Can you hold the phone close enough so the perp can listen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not saying a word, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not about to talk to us.  Maybe to him. Ramey looks back to where the medics are still trying to Stu onto the gurney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget that.  Stand him up. (to Stu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help him over here. The medics support Stu and inch him back to the booth.  I painful, but Stu ignores it. Ramey holds the phone up so Stu can both listen and speak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  Speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into pay phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.  Do you hear me?  Answer me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheezing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to have the last word, Stu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally beat your ass.  Admit it, you fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll never forget me.  I gave you the most thrilling day of your life.  Say thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're gonna die, you bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost a lot of blood.  Don't you want to donate some for me?  Then we'd really be part of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on.  I can't wait to see you at the hospital.  So I can yank your fucking air tube out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could give you that pleasure.  You deserve it. (coughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Only I'm out of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?  At least tell me who you are. There's more violent coughing, then silence.  Then a cop' voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone. Stu stares at the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  We'll find out who he is.  And why he picked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You won't. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to bet you won't? Stu reaches over and hangs up the receiver.  CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll spend my whole life trying to figure that out. Then he sinks into the arms of the medics who lower him o the waiting gurney. The hypo is finally administered.  It kicks in immediatel relieving the pain. He's wheeled away from the booth to the waiting ambulance Kelly is already inside waiting to accompany Stu to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BEING WHEELED AWAY FROM THE EMPTY BOOTH
dialogues.text: pulling away in LOW ANGLE. CAMERA SLIDES BACK inside the ambulance with Stu.  The do shut, obliterating our view of the phone booth that was h entire world until moments ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta sleep now.  No phone calls... Kelly smiles down at him as the image blurs.  Stu passes -- into a deep sleep he much deserves. A SIREN BLARES. CUT TO BLACK.
